title: 114_hr1633
content: The DHS Paid Administrative Leave Accountability Act of 2015, also known as the Department of Homeland Security Improved Internal Tracking and Reporting of Administrative Leave for Personnel Matters, amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to include internal tracking and reporting of administrative leave for personnel matters. The DHS Paid Administrative Leave Accountability Act of 2015 requires each Department component to report the number of employees on administrative leave for 6 months or longer, the total cost associated with such leave, and the average duration of leave. The Chief Human Capital Officer is responsible for tracking employees on administrative leave or paid non-duty status for personnel matters in the Department of Homeland Security. They must maintain records of the number of employees and associated costs, and work with department heads to resolve personnel matters promptly. The Chief Human Capital Officer is responsible for tracking employees on administrative leave or paid non-duty status for personnel matters in the Department of Homeland Security. The term 'personnel matters' includes investigations into misconduct, criminal matters, and adverse actions. The Secretary is encouraged to leverage existing systems to implement the requirements of this section. The table of contents in the Department of Homeland Security Act is amended to include a new item after section 103. SEC. 104 requires internal tracking and reporting of administrative leave for personnel matters within the Department of Homeland Security. The Chief Human Capital Officer of the Department of Homeland Security must develop and implement a policy within 90 days regarding the use of administrative leave and paid non-duty status for personnel matters. This policy will include reporting responsibilities for department components and guidance on resolving personnel matters after 6 months of leave. The policy developed by the Chief Human Capital Officer of the Department of Homeland Security includes guidance on resolving personnel matters after 6 months of leave. SEC. 4. REPORTS TO CONGRESS ON DHS EMPLOYEES ON ADMINISTRATIVE LEAVE FOR PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Chief Human Capital Officer of the Department of Homeland Security must submit quarterly reports to Congress on the number of employees on administrative leave or paid non-duty status for personnel matters, including associated costs and actions taken by the Department. The Chief Human Capital Officer of the Department of Homeland Security must provide quarterly reports to Congress on employees on administrative leave or paid non-duty status for personnel matters, including actions taken by the Department. Section 104(c) of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 was added by section 2 and passed the House of Representatives on June 23, 2015. Karen L. Haas attested to this.
